t: Job 9
Job Replies: There Is No Arbiter
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Truly*pn I know that it is so: But*ld how can a man be in the right before God?
If*ln one wished to contend with him, one*ld could not answer him once in a thousand times.
He*ln is wise in heart and mighty in strength— who has hardened himself against him, and succeeded?—
he*ln who removes mountains, and they know it not, when*ld he overturns them in his anger,
who*ln shakes the earth out of its place, and*ld its pillars tremble;
who*ln commands the sun, and it does not rise; who*ld seals up the stars;
who*ln alone stretched out the heavens and*ld trampled the waves of the sea;
who*ln made the Bear and Orion, the*ld Pleiades and the chambers of the south;
who*ln does great things beyond searching out, and*ld marvelous things beyond number.
Behold,*ln he passes by me, and I see him not; he*ld moves on, but I do not perceive him.
Behold,*ln he snatches away; who can turn him back? Who*ld will say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
“God*pn will not turn back his anger; beneath*ld him bowed the helpers of Rahab.
How*ln then can I answer him, choosing*ld my words with him?
Though*ln I am in the right, I cannot answer him; I*ld must appeal for mercy to my accuser.
If*ln I summoned him and he answered me, I*ld would not believe that he was listening to my voice.
For*ln he crushes me with a tempest and*ld multiplies my wounds without cause;
he*ln will not let me get my breath, but*ld fills me with bitterness.
If*ln it is a contest of strength, behold, he is mighty! If*ld it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?
Though*ln I am in the right, my own mouth would condemn me; though*ld I am blameless, he would prove me perverse.
I*ln am blameless; I regard not myself; I*ld loathe my life.
It*ln is all one; therefore I say, ‘He*ld destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
When*ln disaster brings sudden death, he*ld mocks at the calamity of the innocent.
The*ln earth is given into the hand of the wicked; he*ld covers the faces of its judges— if*ld it is not he, who then is it?
“My*pn days are swifter than a runner; they*ld flee away; they see no good.
They*ln go by like skiffs of reed, like*ld an eagle swooping on the prey.
If*ln I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I*ld will put off my sad face, and be of good cheer,’
I*ln become afraid of all my suffering, for*ld I know you will not hold me innocent.
I*ln shall be condemned; why*ld then do I labor in vain?
If*ln I wash myself with snow and*ld cleanse my hands with lye,
yet*ln you will plunge me into a pit, and*ld my own clothes will abhor me.
For*ln he is not a man, as I am, that I might answer him, that*ld we should come to trial together.
There*ln is no arbiter between us, who*ld might lay his hand on us both.
Let*ln him take his rod away from me, and*ld let not dread of him terrify me.
Then*ln I would speak without fear of him, for*ld I am not so in myself.
